abstract.p: G Randolph Bishop letter contends Immigration and Naturalization Service agents have too much discretion in deciding who should be deported (Anthony Lewis's Sept 23 column)

block.p: Re ''Correcting a Mistake,'' by Anthony Lewis (column, Sept. 23):
Re ''Correcting a Mistake,'' by Anthony Lewis (column, Sept. 23):

The action of the House of Representatives in correcting a cruel legislative mistake that caused immigrants to be deported for minor offenses is laudable. One wonders how any measure so patently unjust was made law in the first place.

Much has been made of the need for Immigration and Naturalization Service agents to use discretion in administering this law, urging them to have ''forbearance.'' But if the use of ''forbearance'' became policy, wouldn't this misplace power and invite arbitrary decisions based on an agent's personal prejudices?

Congress must assume full responsibility for this law, which is creating unnecessary human tragedies in a world already rife with them. There are two obvious ways this could be done: by repealing the law or subjecting deportation measures to judicial review.
G. RANDOLPH BISHOP Sarasota, Fla., Sept. 24, 2000
